ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: In my introduction to Hebrew class, I learned a lot about the basic grammar and syntax of Hebrew. However, I also got the opportunity to learn a lot about the Israeli culture and history through the lens of the language. Dina Roginsky was an incredible, open-minded professor and I felt like I belonged in her class environment.
Really solid foundation of Hebrew

Learned, after coming in with absolutely zero background knowledge, the basics of writing, reading, and speaking modern Hebrew. I also learned a lot about Israeli culture through the songs and ads that we watched.
I gained an elementary proficiency in Modern Hebrew with respect to written, verbal, and listening skills.
How to read/write Hebrew, lots of vocab, verb conjugation in the present tense, basic grammar, etc.
Introductory conversational and written Hebrew vocabulary and grammar.

I learned so much more than I ever expected to in this course, and it was done in such a way that it didn't feel like I was being overwhelmed with material. Big takeaways are solid foundations in the root system, some verb forms, and in the written language (both script and block letters). I must say, the most impressive part of this course is how well you are able to read in Hebrew by the end.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
For strengths, I'd say the class teaches a lot while simultaneously being low-stress. This is nice, as I can learn Hebrew without consistently worrying.
In terms of weaknesses, it is just difficult to meet 4 to 5 times a week. It can feel like a lot.
Lots of homework

Strengths: Prof Dina is fantastic! She gets everyone taking an engaged with the course, it starts out from the basics. The feedback quantity and quality is good. The course is well organized and structured. It provided many opportunities to engage with Israeli and Jewish culture through the Hebrew Tables and cultural events. Very inclusive to all backgrounds and religious beliefs. 

Weaknesses: The work is a lot! It's very very easy to fall behind but Prof Dina and the other students will support and help you catch back up.
The course was very well organized, with opportunities to learn and practice new skills across all language domains (writing, reading, and speaking).

Strengths: Nice variety of assignment, well-structured, quizzes were all take-home, teaching staff was lovely.
Weaknesses: More of a complaint with Yale languages in general, but meeting 5x a week is a lot, and it really limited what other courses I could choose.

The coursework, exercises, and exams are well structured to help students improve in writing and speaking. Each week follows the same structure with different vocabulary and grammar. The course provides a lot of extra resources for those interested.

I had little to no grievances with the course or its structure, so I can't really think of any weaknesses. Biggest strength is its structure, which is really helpful for a class that has students of all different levels and backgrounds with the language. Dina is always prepared and sets up a great structure to learning, so as long as you show up to class (attendance is mandatory!), there is no way that you would not be able to learn the material. I came into this class with absolutely zero familiarity with the language, and there was never a moment where I felt like I was leagues behind any of the other students or that I didn't belong in the class. No matter what level you are, this class is structured for you to succeed so long as you can put forth some effort.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, I would definitely recommend this course. Hebrew is a fun language, but also the class opens your eyes to a lot of culture that you might not know about otherwise.
Yes!! Just be prepared to need to be really committed.

Definitely! As someone who isn't Jewish and had no prior knowledge of the language, I didn't know what to expect coming in but it was the highlight of my semester. You will be shocked with how much of the language you are able to learn in just a couple of months. The small class size makes participation very easy and Prof Dina fosters such a fun, inclusive community for people of any background. But be warned, Modern Hebrew is not for the faint of heart! The daily homework and weekly quizes were definitely overwhelming at times but you just need to trust the process and do what you can to keep up. The work is hard but it is incredibly rewarding! And have I mentioned how great Dina is! TAKE HEBREW!
Absolutely. In a short time, I gained elementary proficiency and can't wait to learn more next semester!

Yes! It's a well-organized class and a great introduction to the language. The workload was pretty manageable, and all of the quizzes were online. If you need a language credit or are at all interested in Hebrew, I recommend it.
Yes, this is the perfect course for anyone who wants to learn Hebrew.

Absolutely, yes. I have taken several languages at Yale, and I have never been so invested in learning a language at Yale until I started taking Hebrew. In most other language courses, a lot of people are taking the class just to get their requirement out of the way, which is totally fine until it's the entire class doing that. Then, it just leads to you feeling like you're just wasting your time every day because no one participates and you spend most of the 50 minutes being cold-called. The way I see it, if I have to be in a class 4-5 times a week, I want to at least take something away from the course. Hebrew offered exactly that. Every person was taking the class for a different reason, and we all came from extremely different backgrounds. I totally anticipated it just being Jewish students, but there was a decent portion of us that weren't Jewish (and also notably a decent number of grad students and international students). I really got to know a lot of people in the class, including Dina, which was truly a treat. All in all, this Hebrew class will go down as one of my favorite classes I have taken at Yale.
